dictate.translation[0].definitions[0].de: to say words for someone else to write down
dictate.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: She’s dictating a letter to her secretary right now.
dictate a letter/memo etc to somebody
dictate.translation[0].definitions[1].de: to tell someone exactly what they must do or how they must behave
dictate.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: Federal funds have to be used as dictated by Washington.
The US government attempted to dictate the terms of the agreement.
The media cannot be allowed to dictate to the government.
Can they dictate how the money will be spent?
Islamic custom dictates that women should be fully covered.
dictate.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: The massive publicity dictated a response from the city government.
Funds dictate what we can do.
The laws of physics dictate that what goes up must come down.
dictate.translation[0].note_box[0].headi: – Meaning 3: to control or influence something
dictate.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: Common sense dictates that you should avoid too much sun.
Circumstances dictated that I had to wait nearly two years.
On the island, custom still dictates the roles of men and women.
Fashion has been dictating that women should wear black for years now.
Logic dictates that this must be the right answer.
Federal laws dictate how land can be used.
dictate.translation[1].definitions[0].de: an order, rule, or principle that you have to obey
dictate.translation[1].definitions[0].ex: teenagers following the dictates of fashion
dictate.translation[2].definitions[0].de: to say words for someone else to write down
dictate.translation[2].definitions[0].ex: When Laurie got back to the office, she dictated a letter to Stewart.
dictate.translation[3].definitions[0].de: an order, rule, or principle that you have to obey
dictate.translation[3].definitions[0].ex: Individual EU countries are free to follow their own dictates on matters concerning the economy.
